perturbation.original_text: The viewing period for each Licensed Program shall be at least twenty-four (24) consecutive hours, or such longer period as may be agreed to by Rogers and Licensor from time to time (the "Viewing Period"). Multiple viewings of the Licensed Program shall be permitted during the Viewing Period for no additional fee and all such viewings shall be considered a single exhibition of the Licensed Program for the purposes of calculating License Fees hereunder.
perturbation.changed_text: The viewing period for each Licensed Program shall be determined by Rogers at its sole discretion (the "Viewing Period"). Additional fees may apply for multiple viewings during the Viewing Period. All viewings shall be considered a single exhibition of the Licensed Program for the purposes of calculating License Fees hereunder.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the legally required minimum viewing period, contradicting consumer protection laws that mandate fair access to purchased digital content. By giving Rogers sole discretion and introducing potential additional fees for multiple viewings, the contract becomes non-compliant with consumer rights regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Consumer Protection Act (Canada) - Fair business practices regarding digital content access.

perturbation.original_text: (b) Notwithstanding Section 6(a) above, (i) Prior to calculating License Fees, Rogers shall be entitled to deduct from Retail Revenues on a rolling monthly basis during the Term ("Rogers Costs"): (A) the value of programming credits, rebates or other retail price discounts provided to ROD Service subscribers in conjunction with a public marketing or promotional initiative; -2- Source: EUROMEDIA HOLDINGS CORP, 10SB12G, 2/15/2007 (B) the value of refunds provided by Rogers to ROD Service subscribers for technical or other errors during such month; (C) the percentage equal to Rogers' average year-to-end bad debt exposure (including credit collection costs) for the then current calendar year in respect of all Rogers' cable television subscribers (expressed as a percentage) (D) encoding costs incurred by Rogers, if applicable, pursuant to Section 8 (a) ; and (E) closed captioning costs incurred by Rogers to comply with Applicable Law.
perturbation.changed_text: (b) Notwithstanding Section 6(a) above, (i) Prior to calculating License Fees, Rogers shall be entitled to deduct from Retail Revenues any costs Rogers deems appropriate. -2- Source: EUROMEDIA HOLDINGS CORP, 10SB12G, 2/15/2007
perturbation.explanation: This change removes specific limitations on deductions from retail revenues, giving Rogers unlimited discretion to deduct costs. This violates consumer protection laws that require transparency and fairness in pricing. The omission enables hidden fees and unpredictable charges, creating a legal contradiction with regulations designed to prevent deceptive pricing practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Competition Act (Canada) - Misleading advertising and deceptive marketing practices.

perturbation.original_text: 27. APPLICABLE LAW. This Agreement is subject to all laws, regulations, license conditions and decisions of the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission ("CRTC") municipal, provincial and federal governments or other authorities which are applicable to Rogers and/or Licensor, and which are now in force or hereafter adopted ("Applicable Law"). In the event that any such law, regulation or decision comes into force during the Term concerning the subject matter of this Agreement, such that it prevents or diminishes either party's ability to perform under this Agreement, the parties agree to enter into good faith negotiations to amend this Agreement, where required, in order to remedy such diminution of or inability to perform.
perturbation.changed_text: 27. APPLICABLE LAW. This Agreement is subject to all laws and regulations applicable to Licensor only. In the event that any such law or regulation comes into force during the Term concerning the subject matter of this Agreement, such that it prevents or diminishes Licensor's ability to perform under this Agreement, the parties agree to enter into good faith negotiations to amend this Agreement, where required, in order to remedy such diminution of or inability to perform.
perturbation.explanation: By limiting the application of laws to only the licensor and removing the explicit mention of the CRTC and other government bodies, the contract attempts to circumvent regulatory oversight and consumer protection mandates that apply to Rogers as a service provider. This omission creates a legal contradiction with Canadian broadcasting regulations and consumer rights laws that govern video-on-demand services.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Broadcasting Act (Canada) - Regulations regarding broadcasting licenses and consumer protection.
